request.description:
To initiate the staking process, create a new flow with a `POST` request to `/api/v1/flows`.

### Parameters

- `flow` — `object`
  - `network_code` — `string` Network this flow operates on (ex. `avalanche`) (required).
  - `chain_code` — `string` Chain this flow operates on (ex. `testnet`) (required).
  - `operation` — `string` The operation to perform (ex. `staking`) (required).
  - `version` — `string` API version to use (ex. `v1`) (optional).

### Response

- `id` — `string` ID of the newly created flow.
- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The response indicates one possible action:

- `create_delegate_tx` — use this action to generate a delegation transaction to stake your AVAX.

The `create_delegate_tx` action indicates five fields for data collection:

- `delegator_address` — The delegating address, where AVAX is being staked from. This must be a P-chain address.
- `validator_address` — Figment's validator address.
- `amount` — The amount of AVAX to be delegated.
- `start_time` — Optional timestamp for when the delegation will be active.
- `end_time` — Optional timestamp for when the delegation will end.
- `memo` — A plaintext memo to identify the transaction.

response.name: Create New Delegation Flow

request.description:
After creating a new staking flow, submit the staking account data. Collect the required inputs. Send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` to proceed to the next step.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `delegator_address` — `string` The delegating address (P-chain) (required).
  - `validator_address` — `string` Address of the validator (required).
  - `amount` — `number` The amount of AVAX to be delegated (required).
  - `start_time` — `number` Adjust if you wish to set a specific delegation start time. [Unix Epoch Timestamp](https://www.unixtimestamp.com/), defaults to five minutes from when the transaction is generated (optional).
  - `end_time` — `number` Adjust if you wish to set a specific delegation end time. [Unix Epoch Timestamp](https://www.unixtimestamp.com/), defaults to the end time of the validator (optional).
  - `memo` — `string` Include a memo with the transaction (optional).

### Response

The response indicates two possible `actions` :

- `refresh_delegate_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction Payload (i.e., the nonce has increased).
- `sign_delegate_tx` — Submit a signed transaction Payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

We will choose `sign_delegate_tx`, which indicates one input to collect:

- `transaction_payload` — The signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

Make sure to save the `transaction_payload` from this response, which is what needs to be signed in the next step.

item.name: Submit Signed Delegate Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
Before broadcasting the transaction, you must [sign the `transaction_payload`](https://docs.figment.io/guides/staking-api/figment-signing-transactions) you received in the previous step. After signing the transaction, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` with the signed payload.
The Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the Avalanche network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
    - `transaction_payload` — Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response.

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, the Staking API will broadcast it to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned state will be either:

- `delegate_tx_broadcasting` — Transaction has been broadcast and is confirming.
- `completed` — Transaction has been confirmed and stake is delegated.

To initiate the transfer process with Staking API, create a new flow with `POST /api/v1/flows`.

### Parameters

- `flow` — `object`
  - `network_code` — `string` Network this flow operates on (ex. `cosmos`) (required).
  - `chain_code` — `string` Chain this flow operates on (ex. `testnet`) (required).
  - `operation` — `string` The operation to perform (ex. `transfer`) (required).
  - `version` — `string` API version to use (ex. `v1`) (optional).

### Response

The response indicates one possible action:

- `create_transfer_tx`

The `create_transfer_tx` action indicates six possible fields for data collection:

- `from_account_address` (required) — The address from which ATOM will be transferred.
- `to_account_address` (required) — The address to which ATOM will be transferred.
- `amount` (required) — The amount of ATOM to be transferred.
- `memo` — an optional message to record on-chain with your transfer.
- `gas_limit` — the total amount of gas you're willing to let this transaction consume.
  - If you do not include this, we'll use a Cosmos library to select a good default for you.
- `gas_price` — how many ATOM you're willing to pay per unit of gas consumed by this transaction.
  - If you do not include this, we'll use a Cosmos library to select a good default for you.

response.name: Create a New Transfer Flow

request.description:
After creating the new transfer flow, we need to submit the transfer data.

After collecting the required inputs as mentioned below, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` to proceed to the next step.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute - `create_transfer_tx`.
- `inputs` — `object`
  - `from_account_address` — `string` The address from which ATOM will be transferred (required).
  - `to_account_address` — `string` The address to which ATOM will be transferred (required).
  - `amount` — `number` The amount of ATOM to be transferred (required).
  - `memo` — `string` A message to record on-chain with your transfer (optional).
  - `gas_limit` — `number` The total amount of gas you're willing to let this transaction consume (optional).
  - `gas_price` — `number` How many ATOM you're willing to pay per unit of gas consumed by this transaction (optional).

### Response

Note that in this step, the Staking API will check that your account balance is greater than or equal to the amount you've submitted for transfer.
Expect an error response if that is not the case.

We see two possible `actions`:

- `refresh_transfer_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction payload (i.e., the nonce has increased).
- `sign_transfer_tx` — Submit a signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

We will choose `sign_transfer_tx`, which indicates one input to collect:

- `transaction_payload` (required) — The signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

Make sure to save the `transaction_payload` from this response, which is what needs to be signed in the next step.

item.name: Submit Signed Transfer Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
Before broadcasting the transaction, you must [sign the `transaction_payload`](https://docs.figment.io/guides/staking-api/figment-signing-transactions) you received in the previous step. After signing the transaction, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` and the Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `transaction_payload` — Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response.

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, the Staking API will broadcast it to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned state will be either:

- `transfer_tx_broadcasting` — Transaction has been broadcast and is waiting for confirmation.
- `completed` — Transaction has been confirmed and the transfer is complete.

- `refresh_withdraw_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction payload (i.e., if the nonce needs to be updated)
- `sign_withdraw_tx` — Submit a signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

We will choose `sign_withdraw_tx`, which indicates one input to collect:

- `transaction_payload` — The signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

Make sure to save the `transaction_payload` from this response, which is what needs to be signed in the next step.

item.name: Submit a Signed Withdraw Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
Before broadcasting the transaction, you must [sign the `transaction_payload`](https://docs.figment.io/guides/staking-api/figment-signing-transactions) you received in the previous step. After signing the transaction, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` (as always!) and the Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the NEAR network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `transaction_payload` — `string` Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response (required).

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, Staking API will broadcast it to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned state will be either:

- `withdraw_tx_broadcasting` — Transaction has been broadcast and is waiting for confirmation.
- `withdrawn` — Transaction has been confirmed and the withdrawal is complete.

response.name: Submit a Signed Withdraw Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
To refresh the transaction state and get the latest status of the existing flow, use the the flow ID from the previous step.

### Parameters

- None

### Response

- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The `state` field will update from `withdraw_tx_broadcasting` to `withdrawn`.

To initiate the transfer process, create a new flow with a `POST` request to `/api/v1/flows`.

### Parameters

- `flow` — `object`
  - `network_code` — `string` Network this flow operates on (ex. `near`) (required).
  - `chain_code` — `string` Chain this flow operates on (ex. `testnet`) (required).
  - `operation` — `string` The operation to perform (ex. `transfer`) (required).
  - `version` — `string` API version to use (ex. `v1`) (optional).

### Response

- `id` — `string` ID of the newly created flow.
- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The response indicates one possible action:

- `create_transfer_tx`

The `create_transfer_tx` action indicates seven fields for data collection:

- `from_account_address` — The address from which NEAR will be transferred.
- `from_account_pubkey` — The account that will sign the transaction.
- `to_account_address` — The address to which NEAR will be transferred.
- `amount` — The amount of NEAR to be transferred.

- `sign_deposit_tx` — Submit a signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

We will choose `sign_deposit_tx`, which indicates one Input to collect:

Make sure to save the `transaction_payload` from this response, which is what needs to be signed in the next step.

request.description:
Use the `assign_stash_and_controller_account` action if you already have a controller account set up and wish to add bond to it.

### Parameters

*   `name` - `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
*   `inputs` - `array`
    *   `controller_account_address` - `string` Address of the wallet DOT will be bonded to (required).
    *   `controller_proxy_account_address` - `string` A proxy account that will sign on behalf of the controller account (optional).
    *   `stash_account_address` - `string` Primary wallet from which DOT will be bonded (required).
    *   `stash_proxy_account_address` - `string` A proxy account that will sign on behalf of the controller account (optional).
    *   `validator_address` - `string` Address of the validator to whom you want to delegate your tokens.
    *   `reward_destination` - `string` Reward destination. (required) Indicates whether rewards are to be:
     1. Added to the staked balance (`staked`)
     2. Sent to the controller account, liquid (`controller`)
     3. Sent to the stash account, liquid (`stash`)
    *   `amount` - `number` - The amount of DOT to be bonded to the controller. This field should be in full DOT, not in Planck (ie. if you want to stake 5 DOT, return "amount": 5.0). Staking API will translate the amount to Plancks so you do not have to worry about the conversion factor (required).

### Response

*   `id` - `string` ID of the newly created flow.
*   `state` - `string` Current state of the flow.
*   `actions` - `array` The actions array contains the name of the next action in the flow and details of the expected inputs in the data field.
    

* * *

response.name: 200 - bonding_complete

request.description:
Use the `create_bonding_tx` action if you do not have a controller account set up and would like to create a controller and bond tokens.

### Parameters

*   `name` - `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
*   `inputs` - `object`
    *   `controller_account_address` - `string` Address of the wallet DOT will be bonded to (required).
    *   `controller_proxy_account_address` - `string` A proxy account that will sign on behalf of the controller account (optional).
    *   `stash_account_address` - `string` Primary wallet from which DOT will be bonded.  Cannot have a zero balance. (required).
    *   `stash_proxy_account_address` - `string` A proxy account that will sign on behalf of the controller account (optional).
    *   `reward_destination` - `string` Reward destination. (required) Indicates whether rewards are to be:
     1.  Added to the staked balance (`Staked`), note the uppercase, `staked` will not work.
     2.  Sent to the controller account, liquid (`Controller`), note the uppercase, `controller` will not work.
     3.  Sent to the stash account, liquid (`Stash`), note the uppercase, `stash` will not work.
    *   `amount` - `number` - The amount of DOT to be bonded to the controller. Minimum of `1.0`. This field should be in full DOT, not in Planck (ie. if you want to stake 5 DOT, return `"amount": 5.0`). Staking API will translate the amount to Plancks so you do not have to worry about the conversion factor (required).

### Response

Note that in this response you can find the unsigned, serialized transaction in `data[create_bonding_tx][raw]`.

*   `id` - `string` ID of the newly created flow.
*   `state` - `string` Current state of the flow.
*   `actions` - `array` The actions array contains the name of the next action in the flow and details of the expected inputs in the data field.

There are two possible `actions`:

- `refresh_bonding_tx` - If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction Payload (i.e., if the nonce needs to be updated).
- `sign_bonding_tx` - Submit a signed transaction Payload ready to be broadcast to the network.
    

* * *

Use `refresh_bonding_tx` if you need to get a fresh version of the transaction Payload (for example, if the nonce needs to be updated).

### Parameters

*   `name` - `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
*   `inputs` - `object` There are no inputs for this action (optional).
    

### Response

The transaction payload is refreshed.

* * *

Use the `sign_bonding_tx` action to submit a signed transaction payload.

### Parameters

*   `name` - `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
*   `inputs` - `array`
    *   `transaction_payload` - `string` Transaction payload can be found in the response after creating the transaction. (required). **OR**
    *   `signatures` - `array` An array of signatures. Staking API will sign the payload if this is provided (optional).

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, Staking API will broadcast it to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned `state` will be `bonding_tx_broadcasting.`

Upon transaction finalization, the bond will be complete and you can move on to the next step — the nomination transaction!

* * *

Use the `create_nomination_tx` action to create the nomination transaction payload.

### Parameters

*   `name` - `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
*   `inputs` - `object`
    *   `validator_addresses` - `array` An array containing the address(es) of the validator(s) to which the DOT will be delegated (required).

You may nominate anywhere from 1 to 16 validators on the Polkadot network. Your DOT will be distributed automatically by the network in the most efficient way at each epoch.

### Response

Note that in this response you can find the unsigned, serialized transaction in `data[create_nomination_tx][raw]`.

*   `id` - `string` ID of the newly created flow.
*   `state` - `string` Current state of the flow.
*   `actions` - `array` The actions array contains the name of the next action in the flow and details of the expected inputs in the data field.

There are two possible `actions`:

*   `refresh_nominate_tx` - If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction Payload.
*   `sign_nomination_tx` - Submit a signed transaction Payload ready to be broadcast to the network.
    

* * *

Use `refresh_nomination_tx` if you need to get a fresh version of the transaction Payload (for example, if the nonce needs to be updated).

### Parameters

*   `name` - `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
*   `inputs` - `object` There are no inputs for this action (optional).
    

### Response

The transaction payload is refreshed.

* * *

Use the `sign_nomination_tx` action to submit a signed transaction payload.

### Parameters

*   `name` - `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
*   `inputs` - `array`
    *   `transaction_payload` - `string` Transaction payload can be found in the response after creating the transaction. (required). **OR**
    *   `signatures` - `array` An array of signatures. Staking API will sign the payload if this is provided (optional).

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, Staking API will broadcast it to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned `state` will be `nomination_tx_broadcasting.`

Since nominations on Polkadot activate at the next epoch boundary (epochs are approximately 1 day), Staking API will also track the nomination and send a webhook notification when it activates.

Upon transaction finalization, the nomination will be complete and your stake is now active and earning rewards.

* * *

To initiate the staking process, create a new flow with a `POST` request to `/api/v1/flows`.

### Parameters

- `flow` — `object`
  - `network_code` — `string` Network this flow operates on (ex. `solana`) (required).
  - `chain_code` — `string` Chain this flow operates on (ex. `testnet`) (required).
  - `operation` `string` The operation to perform (ex. `staking`) (required).
  - `version` — `string` API version to use (ex. `v1`) (optional).


### Response

- `id` — `string` ID of the newly created flow.
- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The response indicates two possible `actions`:

- `assign_stake_account` — Use this action if you already have an inactive stake account you want to activate.
- `create_new_stake_account` — Use this action if you do not have an inactive stake account and want to create a new one.

Since we want to create a new stake account, we will use the second action. The `create_new_stake_account` action indicates four fields for data collection:

- `funding_account_pubkey` — The main wallet your SOL will be originating from.
- `stake_authority_pubkey` — Grants authority to sign certain staking relation transactions to the provided address. Defaults to `funding_account_pubkey`.
- `withdraw_authority_pubkey` — Grants authority to sign certain withdrawal related transactions to the provided address. Defaults to `funding_account_pubkey`.
- `amount` — The amount of SOL to be sent to the stake account. This field should be in full SOL, not in lamports (i.e. if you want to stake 5 SOL, return `"amount": 5.0`). The Staking API will translate the amount to lamports so you do not have to worry about the conversion factor. Lamports are fractional SOLs.

Learn more about account authorities: https://docs.solana.com/staking/stake-accounts#understanding-account-authorities

Learn more about lamports: https://docs.solana.com/terminology#lamport

### Parameters

  - `stake_authority_pubkey` — Grants authority to sign certain staking relation transactions to the provided address. Defaults to `funding_account_pubkey` (optional).
  - `withdraw_authority_pubkey` — Grants authority to sign certain withdrawal related transactions to the provided address. Defaults to `funding_account_pubkey` (optional).
  - `amount` — The amount of SOL to be sent to the Stake Account. This field should be in full SOL, not in lamports (i.e. if you want to stake 5 SOL, return `"amount": 5.0`). The Staking API will translate the amount to lamports so you do not have to worry about the conversion factor (required).

### Response

The response indicates two possible `actions` :

- `refresh_stake_account_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction payload (i.e., the recent blockhash has expired).

We will choose `sign_stake_account_tx`, which indicates one input to collect:

### Parameters

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, Staking API will broadcast it to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned `state` will be either:

- `stake_account_tx_broadcasting` — Transaction has been broadcast but not confirmed.
- `stake_account` — Transaction broadcasted and confirmed.

Upon transaction finalization, the stake account will be ready for the next step — the delegation transaction.

item.name: Submit a Signed Delegate Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
Before broadcasting the transaction, you must [sign the `transaction_payload`](https://docs.figment.io/guides/staking-api/figment-signing-transactions) you received in the previous step. After signing the transaction, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` and the Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the Solana network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `transaction_payload` — Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response.


### Response

With the signed transaction payload provided, the Staking API will broadcast it to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned `state` will be either:

- `delegate_tx_broadcasting` — The delegation transaction has been broadcast but not confirmed.
- `delegation_activating` — The delegation is progressing.
- `delegation_active` — The delegation is active and confirmed.

Since delegations on Solana activate at the next epoch boundary (epochs are approximately 2.5 days), the Staking API will also track the delegation and send a WebHook notification when it activates.

It is possible the delegation will be subjected to a multi-epoch warmup period, in which case you will receive a WebHook notification at each epoch, indicating how much has been activated until the full amount is active.

item.name: Submit a Signed Deactivate Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
Before broadcasting the transaction, you must [sign the `transaction_payload`](https://docs.figment.io/guides/staking-api/figment-signing-transactions) you received in the previous step. After signing the transaction, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` and the Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the Solana network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `transaction_payload` — Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response.

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, Staking API will broadcast it to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned state will be either:

- `deactivate_tx_broadcasting` — Transaction has been broadcast but not confirmed.
- `cool_down` — Transaction is under cool-down period.

Upon transaction finalization, the stake account will start the process of deactivating.
This generally happens at the next epoch boundary (max 2.5 days), but if there is a large change in network-wide delegation levels it is possible it will be subjected to a multi-epoch cooldown period.
This would mean that a portion of the stake will deactivate at each epoch boundary for a few epochs, until it is fully deactivated.

State is now updated from `deactivate_tx_broadcasting` to `cool_down`.

Note - Read more about the [warmup and cooldown period](https://docs.solana.com/cluster/stake-delegation-and-rewards#stake-warmup-cooldown-withdrawal).

At each epoch, a WebHook notifies you about how much of the stake has been deactivated, until it is fully deactivated.

response.name: Get Flow Status

request.description:
After deactivation, we see there is one action — `create_withdraw_tx` — and three required fields for data collection:

- `amount` — The number of SOL to be withdrawn. Partial withdrawal is possible.
- `funding_account_pubkey` — The address of the account that will pay the transaction fee.
- `recipient_pubkey` — The address of the wallet to which the withdrawn SOL will be sent.

Note that the recipient of the withdrawal is _not_ the originating address by default!

Once this data has been collected, submit it to the Staking API:
`PUT /api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next`.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `amount` — `string` The number of SOL to be withdrawn. Partial withdrawal is possible (required).
  - `funding_account_pubkey` — `string` The address of the account that will pay the transaction fee (required).
  - `recipient_pubkey` — `string` the number of SOL to be withdrawn. Partial withdrawal is possible (required).

### Response

Note that, in this response, you can find the unsigned, serialized transaction in `data[create_withdraw_transaction][raw]`.

There are two possible `actions`:

- `refresh_withdraw_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction payload (i.e., the recent blockhash has expired)
- `sign_withdraw_tx` — Submit a signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

We will choose `sign_withdraw_tx`, which indicates one input to collect:

- `transaction_payload` — The signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

The `transaction_payload` you've received in the response make sure to copy/save it because you'll require it in the next step to sign the transaction.

After signing the transaction, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` and the Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the Solana network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `transaction_payload` — Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response.

### Response

And just as in Step 4, Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned state will be:

- `withdraw_tx_broadcasting`

To initiate the transfer process with Staking API, create a new flow with `POST /api/v1/flows`.

### Parameters

- `flow` — `object`
  - `network_code` — `string` Network on which this flow operates (ex. `solana`) (required).
  - `chain_code` — `string` Chain on which this flow operates (ex. `mainnet` , `testnet`) (required).
  - `operation` `string` The operation to perform (ex. `transfer`) (required).
  - `version` — `string` API version to use (ex. `v1`) (optional).

### Response

- `id` — `string` ID of the newly created flow.
- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The response indicates one possible `action`:

- `create_transfer_tx` — Use this action to generate a transfer transaction to move SOL between accounts.

The `create_transfer_tx` action indicates four fields for data collection:

- `funding_account_pubkey` — The public key of the wallet which will pay the transaction fee.
- `from_account_pubkey` — The wallet that SOL will be originating from.
- `to_account_pubkey` — The withdrawal address for the given validator.
- `amount` — The amount of SOL to be transferred to the account. This field should be in full SOL, not in lamports (ie. if you want to transfer 5 SOL, return `"amount": 5.0`). The Staking API will translate the amount to lamports so you do not have to worry about the conversion factor. Lamports are fractional SOLs.

Learn more about lamports here: https://docs.solana.com/terminology#lamport

response.name: Create New Transfer Flow

request.description:
After creating the new transfer flow, we need to submit the transfer data.

After collecting the required inputs as mentioned below, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` to proceed to the next step.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute, such as `create_transfer_tx`
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `from_account_pubkey` — `string` The wallet from which SOL will originate (required).
  - `from_account_address` — `string` The address of the sender's account.
  - `to_account_pubkey` — `string` The address of the wallet to which SOL will be transferred (required).
  - `amount` — `number` — The amount of the tokens you want to transfer (required).

### Response

We see two possible `actions`:

- `refresh_transfer_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction payload (i.e., the recent blockhash has expired).
- `sign_transfer_tx` — Submit a signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

We will choose `sign_transfer_tx`, which indicates one input to collect:

- `transaction_payload` — The signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

Make sure to save the `transaction_payload` from this response, which is what needs to be signed in the next step.

item.name: Submit a Signed Transfer Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
Before broadcasting the transaction, you must [sign the `transaction_payload`](https://docs.figment.io/guides/staking-api/figment-signing-transactions) you received in the previous step. After signing the transaction, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` and the Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `transaction_payload` — Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response.

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, Staking API will broadcast it to the network. As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned state will be:

- `transfer_tx_broadcasting` — Transaction has been broadcast and is awaiting confirmation.

response.name: Submit a Signed Transfer Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
To refresh the transaction state and get the latest status of the existing flow, use the flow ID from the previous step.

### Parameters

- None

### Response

- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The `state` field will update from `transfer_tx_broadcasting` to `transfered`.

To initiate the delegation process, create a new flow with a `POST` request to `/api/v1/flows`.

### Parameters

- `flow` — `object`
  - `network_code` — `string` Network on which this flow operates (ex. `polygon`) (required).
  - `chain_code` — `string` Chain on which this flow operates (ex. `mainnet` , `testnet`) (required).
  - `operation` `string` The operation to perform (ex. `staking`) (required).
  - `version` — `string` API version to use (ex. `v1`) (optional).

### Response

- `id` — `string` ID of the newly created flow.
- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The response indicates one possible action:

- `assign_staking_data` — provide the funding address, validator contract address, and amount of tokens to be staked. The Staking API will check on-chain to determine if an allowance transaction is needed.

The `assign_staking_data` action indicates five fields for data collection:

- `delegator_address` — The main wallet from which MATIC will originate.
- `validator_address` — The validator smart contract address for delegation.
- `amount` — The number of MATIC tokens to be delegated.
- `minimum_shares_to_mint` — The minimum number of shares of the delegation pool to be minted. If the exchange rate results in fewer shares being minted, the transaction will fail.
- `max_slippage_percentage` — The maximum slippage you are willing to accept.

response.name: Create New Delegation Flow

request.description:
After creating a new staking flow, submit the staking account data. Collect the required inputs. Send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` to proceed to the next step.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `delegator_address` — `string` The delegating address (required).
  - `validator_address` — `string` The address of the validator smart contract to which you want to delegate your tokens (required).
  - `amount` — `number` — The amount of MATIC to be delegated (required).
  - `minimum_shares_to_mint` — `string` The minimum number of shares of the delegation pool to be minted. If the exchange rate results in fewer shares being minted, the transaction will fail (optional).
  - `max_slippage_percentage` — `number` The maximum slippage you are willing to accept (optional).

### Response

In the response received from the Staking API we see one possible `action`:

- `create_allowance_tx` — If an allowance transaction is needed.
- `create_delegate_tx` — If no further allowance is needed.

Assuming an allowance is needed, we will proceed with `create_allowance_transaction` which indicates two optional inputs to collect:

- `gas_limit` — The gas limit for the transaction.
- `gas_price` — The highest gas price you will pay for the transaction.

response.name: Submit Staking Data

request.description:
After collecting the required inputs, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` to proceed to the next step.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `gas_limit` — `string` Adjust if you wish to limit the possible transaction fee (optional).
  - `gas_price` — `string` Adjust if you wish to limit the possible transaction fee (optional).

### Response

In this response you can find the unsigned, serialized transaction in `data[create_allowance_tx][raw]`.

There are two possible `actions`:

- `refresh_allowance_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction payload.
- `sign_allowance_tx` — Submit a signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

We will chose `sign_allowance_tx`, so note that it indicates one Input to collect:

- `transaction_payload` — the signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

Make sure to save the `transaction_payload` from this response, which is what needs to be signed in the next step.

item.name: Submit a Signed Allowance Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
Before broadcasting the transaction, you must [sign the `transaction_payload`](https://docs.figment.io/guides/staking-api/figment-signing-transactions) you received in the previous step. After signing the transaction, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` and the Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the Polygon network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `transaction_payload` — Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response.

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, the Staking API will broadcast it to the network.
As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned `state` will be either:

- `allowance_tx_broadcasting` — the transaction has been broadcast but not confirmed.
- `create_delegate_tx` — the transaction has been confirmed, ready for next step in flow.

Upon finalization of the transaction, the account will be ready for the next step to submit the the delegation transaction.

request.description:
To initiate the undelegation process, create a new flow with a `POST` request to `/api/v1/flows`.

### Parameters

- `flow` — `object`
  - `network_code` — `string` Network on which this flow operates (ex. `polygon`) (required).
  - `chain_code` — `string` Chain on which this flow operates (ex. `testnet`) (required).
  - `operation` `string` The operation to perform (ex. `unstaking`) (required).
  - `version` — `string` API version to use (ex. `v1`) (optional).

### Response

- `id` — `string` ID of the newly created flow.
- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The response indicates one possible `action`:

- `create_unbond_tx`

The `create_unbond_tx` action indicates seven fields for data collection:

- `delegator_address` — The delegator address.
- `validator_address` — The validator contract address from which MATIC will be undelegated.
- `amount` — The amount of MATIC to be undelegated.
- `max_shares_to_burn` — The maximum number of shares of the delegation to be burned. If the exchange rate results in more shares being burned, the transaction will fail.
- `max_slippage_percentage` — The maximum slippage you are willing to accept.
- `gas_limit` — Adjust gas limit for the transaction.
- `gas_price` — Adjust gas price for the transaction.

response.name: Create New Undelegation Flow

request.description:
After collecting the required inputs, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` to move on to the next step.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `validator_address` — `string` The validator smart contract address from which MATIC will be undelegated (required).
  - `delegator_address` — `string` The delegator address (required).
  - `amount` — `number` The amount of MATIC to be undelegated (required).

### Response

We see two possible `actions`:

- `refresh_unbond_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction payload (i.e., if the nonce needs to be updated).

We will choose `sign_unbond_tx`, which indicates one input to collect:

item.name: Submit a Signed Unbonding Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
Before broadcasting the transaction, you must [sign the `transaction_payload`](https://docs.figment.io/guides/staking-api/figment-signing-transactions) you received in the previous step. After signing the transaction, you will `PUT /api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` and the Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the Polygon network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `transaction_payload` — Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response.

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, the Staking API will broadcast it to the network.
As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned state will either:

- `unbond_tx_broadcasting` — The transaction has been broadcast and is waiting for confirmation.
- `unbonding` — The transaction has been confirmed and the delegation is unbonding.

response.name: Submit a Signed Unbonding Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
After collecting the required inputs, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` to move on to the next step.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `gas_limit` — `number` Adjust if you wish to limit the possible transaction fee (optional).
  - `gas_price` — `number` Adjust if you wish to limit the possible transaction fee (optional).

### Response

We see two possible `actions`:

- `refresh_claim_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction payload (for example, if the nonce needs to be updated).
- `sign_claim_tx` — Submit a signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

We will choose `sign_claim_tx`, which indicates one input to collect:

- `transaction_payload` — the signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

Make sure to save the `transaction_payload` from this response, which is what needs to be signed in the next step.

item.name: Submit Signed Claim Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
Before broadcasting the transaction, you must [sign the `transaction_payload`](https://docs.figment.io/guides/staking-api/figment-signing-transactions) you received in the previous step. After signing the transaction, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` and the Staking API will broadcast the transaction to the Polygon network.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `transaction_payload` — Signed transaction payload from the previous step's response.

### Response

With the signed transaction provided, the Staking API will broadcast it to the network.
As the transaction progresses towards confirmation, the returned `state` will be either:

- `claim_tx_broadcasting` — The transaction has been broadcast but not confirmed.
- `done` — The transaction has been confirmed and the rewards have been claimed.

response.name: Submit Signed Claim Transaction for Broadcast

request.description:
To refresh the transaction state and get the latest status of the existing flow, send a `GET` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]` using the flow ID from the previous step.

### Parameters

- None

### Response

- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The `state` field will update from `claim_tx_broadcasting` to `done`.

To claim the staking rewards with Staking API firstly we need to create a new Flow with `POST /api/v1/flows`.

### Parameters

- `flow` — `object`
  - `network_code` — `string` Network this flow operates on (ex. `polygon`) (required).
  - `chain_code` — `string` Chain this flow operates on (ex. `mainnet`, `testnet`) (required).
  - `operation` `string` The operation to perform (ex. `claim_rewards`) (required).
  - `version` — `string` API version to use (ex. `v1`) (optional).

### Response

- `id` — `string` ID of the newly created flow.
- `state` — `string` The current state of the flow.

The response indicates one possible `action`:

- `create_claim_rewards_tx` -

The `create_claim_rewards_tx` action indicates four fields for data collection:

- `delegator_address` — The address delegating MATIC.
- `validator_address` — The Validator contract address to which MATIC are delegated.
- `gas_limit` — Adjust gas limit for the claim transaction.
- `gas_price` — Adjust gas price for the claim transaction.

response.name: Create New Claim Rewards Flow

request.description:
After collecting the required inputs, send a `PUT` request to `/api/v1/flows/[:flow_id]/next` to move on to the next step.

### Parameters

- `name` — `string` Name of the action to execute (required).
- `inputs` — `array`
  - `delegator_address` — `string` The address delegating MATIC (required).
  - `validator_address` — `string` The Validator contract address to which MATIC are delegated (required).
  - `gas_limit` — `number` Adjust gas limit for the claim transaction (optional).
  - `gas_price` — `number` Adjust gas limit for the claim transaction (optional).

### Response

The response indicates two possible `actions` :

- `refresh_claim_rewards_tx` — If you need to get a fresh version of the transaction payload (for example, if the nonce needs to be updated).
- `sign_claim_rewards_tx ` — Submit a signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

We will choose `sign_claim_rewards_tx`, which indicates one input to collect:

- `transaction_payload` — the signed transaction payload ready to be broadcast to the network.

Make sure to save the `transaction_payload` from this response, which is what needs to be signed in the next step.
